reasoning: The critique targets a central optimistic channel in the essay: that partial AM-convergence plus bargaining/trade can still yield mostly-great futures. If many powerful agents have constraint/lexical/anti-compromise values (e.g., “this must not happen anywhere”), then large mutual gains from trade can collapse, weakening that channel substantially—so centrality is high. The argument is conceptually strong (lexical constraints imply effectively infinite prices, undermining Nash-style compromise), but its force depends on an empirical/psychological premise the critique doesn’t establish: that such anti-compromise psychologies are common and decisive in post-AGI bargaining. Also, the essay partially anticipates related problems (e.g., threats, bads outweighing goods, separate aggregation, low resource-compatibility among linear views), so this isn’t a full refutation but does add an important failure mode. The critique is mostly correct but somewhat overstated in implying infeasibility “except via coercion or deception,” since some constraints may be local or satisfiable via partitioning. It is clear, focused, and has little extraneous material.
title: Lexical no-compromise moral constraints collapse the paper’s trade-based optimism channel
